title: St Philip's Church, Alderley Edge
text:
St Philip's Church is in the village of <a href="Alderley%20Edge">Alderley Edge</a>, <a href="Cheshire">Cheshire</a>, England. The church is recorded in the <a href="National%20Heritage%20List%20for%20England">National Heritage List for England</a> as a designated Grade II* <a href="Listed%20building%23England%20and%20Wales">listed building</a>. It is an active <a href="Anglican">Anglican</a> <a href="parish%20church">parish church</a> in the <a href="diocese%20of%20Chester">diocese of Chester</a>, the archdeaconry of Macclesfield and the deanery of Knutsford. The architectural historian <a href="Nikolaus%20Pevsner">Nikolaus Pevsner</a> described it as "large, ambitious, and unmistakably prosperous-looking".
History.
St Philip's was designed by the <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a> architect <a href="J.%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BS.%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BCrowther">J. S. Crowther</a>, and was his first independent work. It originated in 1851–52 when the <a href="nave">nave</a>, the south <a href="aisle">aisle</a> and the <a href="chancel">chancel</a> were built. In 1856–57 the north aisle, a further <a href="bay%20%28architecture%29">bay</a> on the west of the church, and a <a href="Steeple%20%28architecture%29">steeple</a> to the south of the church, were added. A <a href="vestry">vestry</a> was added in 1903 to a design by F. P. Oakley.
Architecture.
Exterior.
The church is built in hammer-dressed <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a> <a href="rubble">rubble</a> with <a href="ashlar">ashlar</a> dressings. The <a href="slate">slate</a> roof is in bands of three colours. Its architectural style is <a href="English%20Gothic%20architecture%23Decorated%20Gothic">Decorated</a>. The plan of the church consists of a six-<a href="Bay%20%28architecture%29">bay</a> nave with north and south aisles, each under its own ridge, a three-bay <a href="chancel">chancel</a>, a hexagonal vestry, and a southwest tower with a spire. The tower is in four stages with angle <a href="buttress">buttress</a>es and the spire has three levels of <a href="lucarne">lucarne</a>s.
Interior.
In the north wall of the chancel is a <a href="sedilia">sedilia</a>, and in the south wall is a <a href="piscina">piscina</a>. The carved <a href="reredos">reredos</a> of 1903 depicts the <a href="Last%20Supper">Last Supper</a>. The choir stalls, <a href="pulpit">pulpit</a> and organ screen, all dated 1907, are panelled. These were designed by <a href="Percy%20Worthington">Percy Worthington</a>. In the south aisle is a stained glass window made by <a href="Morris%20%26amp%3B%20Co.">Morris & Co.</a> dating from 1873. These include figures designed by <a href="Edward%20Burne-Jones">Edward Burne-Jones</a> and <a href="Ford%20Madox%20Brown">Ford Madox Brown</a>. Elsewhere are windows dating from 1933 to 1935 by <a href="James%20Powell%20and%20Sons">Powells</a>. The three-<a href="manual%20%28music%29">manual</a> organ was built by Wadsworth of <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a> and was rebuilt in 1962 by Jardine and Company, also of Manchester.
